73C4B471D8534B58A95262F85D0C6A9E.description: PUN 702. Use a colon to introduce an example or an elaboration

1B03E6C40A814BAB9A8E05BE34807633.description: PUN 701. Delete punctuation around essential/restrictive appositives or clauses

773650CF6BA34F259C559B462B390EC3.description: PUN 604. Use a semicolon to link closely related independent clauses

13865501482D42E5AA5E392AC558A2F9.description: PUN 603. Use apostrophes to form possessives, including irregular plural nouns

CF1C6A7E79964776A1D7495F2A70E807.description: PUN 602. Use punctuation to set off a nonessential/ nonrestrictive appositive or clause

6C794831B8AB4D15B632C512C4A7A1F4.description: PUN 601. Use commas to avoid ambiguity when the syntax or language is sophisticated (e.g., to set off a complex series of items)

8EED681A0DB14CFE96740BE4267BCE44.description: PUN 504. Use apostrophes to form simple possessive nouns

0825A63798FA4E5ABB5DD3678FFAA567.description: PUN 503. Use punctuation to set off complex parenthetical elements

3855EADC1FA544F689591E3F9640A096.description: PUN 502. Recognize and correct inappropriate uses of colons and semicolons

DC25A1C64C5A467B87DED9224E684771.description: PUN 501. Delete commas in long or involved sentences when an incorrect understanding of the sentence suggests a pause that should be punctuated (e.g., between the elements of a compound subject or compound verb joined by and)

D2FEDB33ECE64E6A8A064874DED01DC4.description: PUN 404. Use commas to set off simple parenthetical elements

573060444DF94ABF99ABDBE9A218D492.description: PUN 403. Use commas to avoid obvious ambiguity (e.g., to set off a long introductory element from the rest of the sentence when a misreading is possible)

CA0F2072656543D2956FCFFE0FB3D750.description: PUN 402. Delete apostrophes used incorrectly to form plural nouns

6DBFE0F3CCDE481CA78DE8802D877CDB.description: PUN 401. Delete commas when an incorrect understanding of the sentence suggests a pause that should be punctuated (e.g., between verb and direct object clause)

2D88A3F6808D47BE9156DCD40B47CFD2.description: PUN 302. Use appropriate punctuation in straightforward situations (e.g., simple items in a series)

B19C25F7862B46939A92B21B77BF31BB.description: PUN 301. Delete commas that markedly disturb sentence flow (e.g., between modifier and modified element)

0E4FF4F21F95443F8FC66FD5851A0C21.description: PUN 201. Delete commas that create basic sense problems (e.g., between verb and direct object)

1CBFCC447EAD4C86BC74D5F8BAE8924E.description: USG 702. Use idiomatically and contextually appropriate prepositions in combination with verbs in situations involving sophisticated language or complex concepts

408F9886463F4A7385A4131D3E6ED9CF.description: USG 701. Ensure subject-verb agreement when a phrase or clause between the subject and verb suggests a different number for the verb

C704902D304B4426A2D9E1E59B735357.description: USG 603. Use the appropriate word in less-common confused pairs (e.g., allude and elude)

035DC3DC82F0463D89F930B71C0B91E7.description: USG 602. Correctly use reflexive pronouns, the possessive pronouns its and your, and the relative pronouns who and whom

0BA7E30BD2F64C489CBACD79F7BA2178.description: USG 601. Ensure subject-verb agreement in some challenging situations (e.g., when the subject-verb order is inverted or when the subject is an indefinite pronoun)

76AAB68FBF8B42B1BF212590EC7BA13E.description: USG 503. Recognize and correct vague and ambiguous pronouns

8D1253B4BB60455FAAE7E26ACAA682D3.description: USG 502. Ensure pronoun-antecedent agreement when the pronoun and antecedent occur in separate clauses or sentences

F9C9B354145D4C93A3DF355CDC694345.description: USG 501. Form simple and compound verb tenses, both regular and irregular, including forming verbs by using have rather than of (e.g., would have gone, not would of gone)

9AEA84431C53404B935A131F6D1F01A1.description: USG 404. Recognize and correct expressions that deviate from idiomatic English

8B2259305ECB494F8A5D6B19D23BF643.description: USG 403. Use idiomatically appropriate prepositions, especially in combination with verbs (e.g., long for, appeal to)

5F77008B948E46D08AFEF13387220B71.description: USG 402. Ensure subject-verb agreement when there is some text between the subject and verb

0F67F54BA1FC41ABAB68337325781DA1.description: USG 401. Use the correct comparative or superlative adjective or adverb form depending on context (e.g., “He is the oldest of my three brothers”)

9B68C0A3027044F5944BA42A2399086E.description: USG 305. Use the appropriate word in frequently confused pairs (e.g., there and their, past and passed, led and lead)

927BE5604717407694C1A8CE15CDA6DC.description: USG 304. Use idiomatically appropriate prepositions in simple contexts

B1DC7CF3025449CA90113A8B344997E6.description: USG 301. Determine whether an adjective form or an adverb form is called for in a given situation

A3532305F2124FC7B0141B0DA06C783A.description: USG 202. Form comparative and superlative adjectives

887C3B8B66EB43139533F8256748E125.description: USG 201. Form the past tense and past participle of irregular but commonly used verbs

EE52EB531A204057B2F9B6ADDD813080.description: SST 701. Recognize and correct very subtle disturbances in sentence structure (e.g., weak conjunctions between independent clauses, run-ons that would be acceptable in conversational English, lack of parallelism within a complex series of phrases or clauses)

F09E3BA4D4464AF29CA6BA89F03DC04C.description: SST 602. Maintain consistent and logical verb tense and voice and pronoun person on the basis of the paragraph or essay as a whole

303657616C764EBE9D70EB6872DD628B.description: SST 601. Recognize and correct subtle disturbances in sentence structure (e.g., danglers where the intended meaning is clear but the sentence is ungrammatical, faulty subordination and coordination of clauses in long or involved sentences)

44A2E98E5043423499F72D4379A9C839.description: SST 502. Maintain consistent and logical verb tense and pronoun person on the basis of the preceding clause or sentence

3EA84E1A0C004FCC94232EA2FBF11C7C.description: SST 501. Recognize and correct disturbances in sentence structure (e.g., faulty placement of phrases, faulty coordination and subordination of clauses, lack of parallelism within a simple series of phrases)

974F833CCBB849F2A8288386A660E0E0.description: SST 401. Recognize and correct marked disturbances in sentence structure (e.g., faulty placement of adjectives, participial phrase fragments, missing or incorrect relative pronouns, dangling or misplaced modifiers, lack of parallelism within a simple series of verbs)

D26E20D6B29B4CDF853AF0C0612881C4.description: SST 302. Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb tense and voice when the meaning of the entire sentence must be considered

F1D0FE9EDF7E490194EF3C4805B11E72.description: SST 301. Determine the need for punctuation or conjunctions to correct awkward-sounding fragments and fused sentences as well as obviously faulty subordination and coordination of clauses

A9F77D9FFAB14ABCBE2B4C84D40082D4.description: SST 202. Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb tense between simple clauses in a sentence or between simple adjoining sentences

FCE892564C63465799FDE5F2C44B8B14.description: SST 201. Determine the need for punctuation or conjunctions to join simple clauses

94858FEDAE444473B856D3C936387A8A.description: KLA 702. Use the word or phrase most appropriate in terms of the content of the sentence when the vocabulary is sophisticated

B675EB5E2EEF4C24843CE513D07E5E34.description: KLA 701. Delete redundant and wordy material that involves sophisticated language or complex concepts or where the material is redundant in terms of the paragraph or essay as a whole

671B692DBCB9416F91FDEC043EF9F2C3.description: KLA 604. Use the word or phrase most appropriate in terms of the content of the sentence when the vocabulary is fairly sophisticated

19E15F291E644405886F9AE6025D9E33.description: KLA 603. Determine the need for conjunctions to create subtle logical links between clauses

1440847E62A541BA9719DC89FAB1C197.description: KLA 602. Delete redundant and wordy material that involves fairly sophisticated language (e.g., “the outlook of an aesthetic viewpoint”) or that sounds acceptable as conversational English

2855F69033F242BCB4365DB1B452BCD7.description: KLA 601. Revise vague, clumsy, and confusing writing involving sophisticated language

79C1D8BEA6C34631B90CD5B6BF810BDB.description: KLA 505. Use the word or phrase most appropriate in terms of the content of the sentence when the vocabulary is uncommon

C417389FC58248F6B5801DB181AF4D4C.description: KLA 504. Determine the need for conjunctions to create logical links between clauses

4869D7594BB74C69A6997FB8FB97851D.description: KLA 503. Revise expressions that deviate in subtle ways from the style and tone of the essay

03E756B6718C41ECA9AC374C8A30C00A.description: KLA 502. Delete redundant and wordy material when the meaning of the entire sentence must be considered

15610805A4E1425E8703BE8D28AD92F5.description: KLA 501. Revise vague, clumsy, and confusing writing

6146F824026F42C585CF27442B2C3729.description: KLA 404. Use the word or phrase most appropriate in terms of the content of the sentence when the vocabulary is relatively common

700CE5ED92784E19A69AD7DB592C5C47.description: KLA 403. Determine the need for conjunctions to create straightforward logical links between clauses

BF565DF1412F484B982237E900CB7F54.description: KLA 402. Revise expressions that deviate from the style and tone of the essay

EA7DC94169CB4D7698C52FF596C9BD54.description: KLA 401. Delete redundant and wordy material when the problem is contained within a single phrase (e.g., “alarmingly startled,” “started by reaching the point of beginning”)

4A46C43923FE4E988114A83EC5533106.description: KLA 302. Revise expressions that deviate markedly from the style and tone of the essay

45D6E56EA3124471BACDDAFACD0BD084.description: KLA 301. Delete obviously redundant and wordy material

412BD3B343A84C36A1CB2185338E4149.description: KLA 201. Revise vague, clumsy, and confusing writing that creates obvious logic problems

5D67D64338F94CE886F271444B4B728E.description: ORG 702. Provide a sophisticated introduction or conclusion to or transition within a paragraph or essay, basing decisions on a thorough understanding of the paragraph and essay (e.g., linking the conclusion to one of the essay’s main images)

F1D89B12DFA04E7697E5429AEE8F1875.description: ORG 701. Determine the need for transition words or phrases, basing decisions on a thorough understanding of the paragraph and essay

28FBC85FF5A14B03AACBD438964FF763.description: ORG 604. Rearrange the sentences in a fairly complex paragraph for the sake of logic and coherence

64BBE7B36C944FB0810A10F923FE9195.description: ORG 603. Provide a subtle introduction or conclusion to or transition within a paragraph or essay (e.g., echoing an essay’s theme or restating the main argument)

20A91DA2BB654AD89A4945F60DD54EEB.description: ORG 602. Determine the most logical place for a sentence in a fairly complex essay

C0DD67D719FD4ED9975C665A755ECDF7.description: ORG 601. Determine the need for transition words or phrases to establish subtle logical relationships within and between paragraphs

0784244990834F7F8A40712DD162878F.description: ORG 505. Rearrange the paragraphs in an essay for the sake of logic

A625D4CCDA59441BA78F12EC2E0E2A63.description: ORG 504. Determine the best place to divide a paragraph to meet a particular rhetorical goal

B30C172A3953449B8B396C8FF5F82C53.description: ORG 503. Rearrange the sentences in a fairly straightforward paragraph for the sake of logic

A65BF2B6A86946D49B0908C12D5CE35B.description: ORG 502. Provide a fairly straightforward introduction or conclusion to or transition within a paragraph or essay (e.g., supporting or emphasizing an essay’s main idea)

4F7C9FAEC68E4D98953520E66700C9CB.description: ORG 501. Determine the need for transition words or phrases to establish subtle logical relationships within and between sentences (e.g., therefore, however, in addition)

492130A8593346A68832392B7F3C4156.description: ORG 405. Rearrange the sentences in a straightforward paragraph for the sake of logic

84C2353930984558AAD903475322C36D.description: ORG 404. Provide a straightforward conclusion to a paragraph or essay (e.g., summarizing an essay’s main idea or ideas)

83C2BB35E2834052ABA5C84A48537FE8.description: ORG 403. Provide an introduction to a straightforward paragraph

A9A7C685563C4AA69A7D394073606E5C.description: ORG 402. Determine the most logical place for a sentence in a straightforward essay

4CAFCAEAC5B44145AF57A661C0CC5D6C.description: ORG 401. Determine the need for transition words or phrases to establish straightforward logical relationships (e.g., first, afterward, in response)

B70E4C60A20F4635BF91128728405204.description: ORG 302. Provide a simple conclusion to a paragraph or essay (e.g., expressing one of the essay’s main ideas)

5115CDD471CB469C9F0DDFB6BA5EC7B8.description: ORG 301. Determine the most logical place for a sentence in a paragraph

ECC23BB56DDC4B25A926368AA9679531.description: ORG 201. Determine the need for transition words or phrases to establish time relationships in simple narrative essays (e.g., then, this time)

6238208E16C54CD99455018021E32D82.description: TOD 703. Use a word, phrase, or sentence to accomplish a complex purpose, often in terms of the focus of the essay

F0095C92E3344520B6664AE67B9EC238.description: TOD 702. Determine whether a complex essay has met a specified goal

66797E317D3B47BE80FA7F3C4EFA01ED.description: TOD 701. Identify the purpose of a word, phrase, or sentence when the purpose is complex (e.g., anticipating a reader’s need for background information) or requires a thorough understanding of the paragraph and essay

C0CA1810DF2F4AAF9684592BC7F67326.description: TOD 603. Use a word, phrase, or sentence to accomplish a subtle purpose (e.g., adding emphasis or supporting detail, expressing meaning through connotation)

CC65385649BD4A859DECA432EBAC1FBF.description: TOD 602. Identify the purpose of a word, phrase, or sentence when the purpose is subtle (e.g., supporting a later point, establishing tone) or when the best decision is to delete the text in question

8BAA3ADB9E984A2082D99CF3E977FB5D.description: TOD 601. Determine relevance when considering material that is plausible but potentially irrelevant at a given point in the essay

6DE030128EAB4AF597BBCCDDF55B4659.description: TOD 504. Use a word, phrase, or sentence to accomplish a fairly straightforward purpose (e.g., sharpening an essay’s focus, illustrating a given statement)

3ACA512E8709482AB34A0EB38B3E98CF.description: TOD 503. Determine whether an essay has met a specified goal

0CB108853FC1427AB61655BBA91D3EDE.description: TOD 502. Identify the purpose of a word, phrase, or sentence when the purpose is fairly straightforward (e.g., identifying traits, giving reasons, explaining motivations)

DF50269E2A17417D994DB0F5120B0CD4.description: TOD 501. Determine relevance of material in terms of the focus of the paragraph

3D63301D232E4DEE96D43D144C91C1A1.description: TOD 403. Use a word, phrase, or sentence to accomplish a straightforward purpose (e.g., conveying a feeling or attitude)

6914F11B66C140E899BE2F53998F17D8.description: TOD 402. Identify the purpose of a word or phrase when the purpose is straightforward (e.g., describing a person, giving examples)

B05A8288436E4F62A31C20320EADD964.description: TOD 401. Determine relevance of material in terms of the focus of the essay

A724B8F6E30E4A5688DFECFC6D513F4D.description: TOD 303. Determine whether a simple essay has met a straightforward goal

182E232F59BB4E0181015C579897E8B1.description: TOD 302. Identify the purpose of a word or phrase when the purpose is simple (e.g., identifying a person, defining a basic term, using common descriptive adjectives)

C2A0107CF31D40DB9A53410CCFE04D46.description: TOD 301. Delete material because it is obviously irrelevant in terms of the focus of the essay

A51E169C53B4464194B7E5C12CD75F00.description: TOD 201. Delete material because it is obviously irrelevant in terms of the topic of the essay
